choices.D: a second Ethernet interface for remote access.
choices.A: an SD card with a backup configuration.
choices.B: a TFTP server on the main network for backup configurations.

questions.question_text: A network administrator plans to install network connectivity at a new remote office location. The administrator is concerned about how to troubleshoot network connectivity issues and reconfigure the remote router. The technician should use __________.

discussion.content: Its Out-Of-Band-Management, it is done via Modem. SD card won't work remotely m sure. C is the correct answer.

Given answer makes no sense to me : (C. a modem using POTS.)
Passleader shows the answer as : A.) an SD card with a backup config

comments.content: From my understanding, for him to work on a remote router with the wan possibly being fown would require a modem using pots. The tech wouldn't be able to remote in using ssh since no internet, but a modem using pots would allow him to establish an alternative connection.
Can you explain how a technician would troubleshoot the router through the modem with POTS? I asked one of my profs and he can't provide an explanation, thanks in advance!
This seems to be a "out of band" question. remote office location, needs to troubleshoot but concerned with network connectivity. A POTS network via a V.92 modem is an alternative method.

choices.C: The installation of two switches to divide the Internet from the LAN and the LAN to the DMZ.
choices.D: The installation of a switch from the Internet to the DMZ and a firewall between the DMZ and the LAN.
choices.A: The installation of a firewall with multiple interfaces for the Internet to the DMZ and the LAN.
choices.B: The in-line installation of two firewalls to divide the Internet to the DMZ and the DMZ to the LAN.

comments.content: According to this site, "There are numerous ways to construct a network with a DMZ. The two major methods are a single firewall (sometimes called a three-legged model), or dual firewalls." which means that the given answer is correct because it's one way to install a DMZ.

discussion.content: A Dmz has already 2 firewalls. It is meaningless to install additional 2 firewalls over a DMZ.

Can we get some clarification? 
Given answer here is B, I see this Q elsewhere with the answer given as C

comments.content: Your keywords here are "separate devices to protect", so determine which devices protect out of the choices provided. There is only one answer provided that gives you two separate firewalls, using a single firewall with multiple interfaces is redundant because you'd only have to break through one firewall to penetrate the network and DMZ. Having separate firewalls with different standards is best.

questions.question_text: A consultant is designing a new network for a company that will be hosting its own email and web servers. The company wants to ensure there are separate devices to protect the internal network from the DMZ and the DMZ from the Internet. Which of the following would provide this protection?
Which of the following BEST explains why a network engineer would use a wireless mesh network when connecting sensors to a sensor gateway?

discussion.content: Mesh topology provides various paths to a destination and thus redundancy.
NO, It's C, mesh topology provide redundancy.

comments.content: It does provide redundancy, but C says "if the sensor network experiences broad wireless interference". The keyword is broad, meaning it affects the whole network. There won't be any redundancy if everything goes down.

choices.A: It creates various paths to a particular destination.
choices.B: It increases the overall throughput of the links connecting the devices.
choices.C: It provides redundancy if the sensor network experiences broad wireless interference.
choices.D: It allows autonomous communication if the sensor network goes down.

discussion.content: You guys should know that if the wireless frequency is different, they wouldn't be able to connect at all (won't be able to see the SSID)

comments.content: The key is just the password to for the connection, not the encryption standard being used, i.e. WEP, WPA, WP2, etc

A user cant decide to change the encryption standard. That is done at the router and we know other users are connected. I would say B as well. Maybe we have an older model 2.4ghz trying to connect to a 5ghz network.
I thought that too, but then realized that a 2.4Ghz device wouldn't even be able to see the network. "The user is connecting to the correct SSID" implies that they're able to attempt to connect.
When connecting to a wlan you can choose to set the encryption type used manually. You would never do this in the real world but it applies to this question.

discussion.content: I am not sure how the given answer of 'D' (encryption type) is correct. The Q states he had the correct Key. B (Wireless Freq) makes more sense to me. A+C are definitely ruled out

questions.question_text: A network technician is assisting a user who cannot connect to a wireless connection. The user is connecting to the correct SSID and has the correct pre-shared key. The technician verifies the WAP is working, and other clients are connected to it from the same location. Which of the following should the technician investigate?

comments.content: Motion detection alarms do not prevent theft

discussion.content: Keyword prevent. The only physical measure that will prevent a thief from stealing equipment is the lock. The asset tracking tags can help you find it, but they can not stop a thief from stealing.
ma che cazzo di te dio povero porco dio merda stronzo il porco

questions.question_text: As part of a new datacenter upgrade project, the security manager has asked for additional physical security to prevent asset theft. Which of the following technologies should be implemented?
